bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, April 16, 1929

div1.p: Carter waits to hear from Frost about finalizing work on the manuscript and continues to work on bibliographical references for the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, April 16, 1929

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
April 16, 1929.

div1.p:
I have put off writing to you a few days beyond the time of
my usual weekly report in the hope of being able to tell you that I
had heard from Dr. Frost as to just when he wanted me in Baltimore.
Nothing yet, however, but I feel sure that I will get news soon that
things have been so cleared up at his “end of the line” that the final
revision of Father's MS. can be resumed.

In the meantime, Miss Brown and I continue our work on the--
fortunately!--constantly “diminishing” bibliographic “returns.” We
put in a very satisfactory evening together last Wednesday and have also
gotten some good results working apart. I had intended going down to the Library
of Congress once or twice last week, not because I could work better there
than at home, at this particular stage of the work, but because, as I
wrote you before, I don't want to stay away too long at a time from the
space there reserved for me. However, owing to a gastro-intestinal upset,
I decided I could accomplish much more by working at home and having Miss
Brown bring me the needed reference books, thus avoiding the fatigue
and longer hours of the trip across town to the Library and back.

I received a most interesting letter from Dr. Alfred M. Tozzer, of
the Division of Anthropology of Harvard last week. This in reply to a
letter I had written him re a statement attributed to the Anales of Chi-
malpahin. He didn't have a copy of the Anales, so couldn't give me the
exact pagination, but he suggested a lot of helpful “side lines,” by
which Miss Brown and I may be able to get our data. He really took a lot
of trouble and I am correspondingly grateful, as I am writing to inform
him.

I am expecting Miss Brown out again to-night, unless I have
the good luck to hear from Dr. Frost in the interim.
With very best wishes, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
